{"abstract": "The United States Patent and Trademark Office upheld Procter & Gamble\u2019s patent used for a Folgers-brand plastic coffee container.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/08/business/08bizbriefs-PATENTOFFICE_BRF.html", "snippet": "The United States Patent and Trademark Office upheld Procter & Gamble\u2019s patent used for a Folgers-brand plastic coffee container.", "lead_paragraph": " Procter & Gamble said the United States Patent and Trademark Office upheld its patent used for a Folgers-brand plastic coffee container. The ruling clears a hurdle for P.& G.\u2019s patent-infringement lawsuit against Kraft Foods, claiming Maxwell House coffee packaging violates its property. P.& G. began selling Folgers in a plastic container in 2003, saying the tubs better preserved freshness and helped increase sales. A Kraft spokeswoman described the ruling as procedural and said the company did not infringe valid patents. {"abstract": "Ads for tampon brands have grown less oblique in recent years, and a new campaign for Tampax uses candor and even humor.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/20/business/media/20adco.html", "snippet": "Ads for tampon brands have grown less oblique in recent years, and a new campaign for Tampax uses candor and even humor.", "lead_paragraph": "ADVERTISING spots for tampon brands historically have been among the most euphemistic on television, featuring women riding horses along the beach or twirling in fields of flowers, while voice-overs assure that the products will instill \u201cconfidence\u201d and \u201cfreshness.\u201d ", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "7", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "A Campaign That Erases a Layer of Euphemisms", "kicker": "Advertising", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "A Campaign That Erases A Layer of Euphemisms", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Women", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Menstruation", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "ADVERTISING AND MARKETING", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Procter & Gamble Co", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2009-03-19T23:40:44+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Andrew Adam Newman", "person": [{"firstname": "Andrew", "middlename": "Adam", "lastname": "Newman", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/7737e351-d824-5706-804e-1f7b69eb1986", "word_count": 1100, "uri": "nyt://article/7737e351-d824-5706-804e-1f7b69eb1986"}

{"abstract": "Old Spice is pushing the notion \u201cResidue Is Evil,\u201d with bizarre ads to persuade men to use its new Ever Clear deodorant line.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/17/business/media/17adco.html", "snippet": "Old Spice is pushing the notion \u201cResidue Is Evil,\u201d with bizarre ads to persuade men to use its new Ever Clear deodorant line.", "lead_paragraph": "IN a print ad for Ever Clear, a new men\u2019s antiperspirant from Old Spice, a male in his 20s stands on a beach. Waving and smiling, he is clearly unaware that, dangling from his underarm to nearly his knee, is the word \u201cidiot,\u201d spelled out in white, foamy letters, which match bits of deodorant visible in his armpit. A bikini-clad woman looks up from a magazine at him, and the copy reads, \u201cResidue Is Evil. {"abstract": "Using creative videos, Old Spice aggressively markets to women shower gel made for men. But will real men abandon bar soap for body wash?", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/16/business/media/16adco.html", "snippet": "Using creative videos, Old Spice aggressively markets to women shower gel made for men. But will real men abandon bar soap for body wash?", "lead_paragraph": "WHEN Old Spice, the 72-year-old Procter & Gamble brand, was planning a new advertising campaign for shower gel earlier this year, it faced a challenge: its research suggested women purchase as much as 70 percent of the shower gel for men in their households, but using body wash struck some men as unmanly. How could they market body wash to female purchasers and yet still cast the product as decidedly masculine to lure men away from bar soap?", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "3", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "thumbnail", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2010/07/16/business/16Adco/16Adco-thumbStandard.jpg", "height": 75, "width": 75, "subType": "thumbnail", "crop_name": "thumbStandard", "legacy": {"thumbnail": "images/2010/07/16/business/16Adco/16Adco-thumbStandard.jpg", "thumbnailwidth": 75, "thumbnailheight": 75}}], "headline": {"main": "Old Spice Argues That Real Men Smell Good", "kicker": "Advertising", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Old Spice Argues That Real Men Smell Good", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Online Advertising", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Procter & Gamble Co", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Wieden & Kennedy", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2010-07-15T18:12:41+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Andrew Adam Newman", "person": [{"firstname": "Andrew", "middlename": "Adam", "lastname": "Newman", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/b5f64c75-8f4e-5041-9ed5-17b118b31220", "word_count": 988, "uri": "nyt://article/b5f64c75-8f4e-5041-9ed5-17b118b31220"}

{"abstract": "A Febreze air freshener marketing campaign is directed at women and aims in part to debunk the gender stereotype that women are not N.F.L. fans.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/03/business/media/03adco.html", "snippet": "A Febreze air freshener marketing campaign is directed at women and aims in part to debunk the gender stereotype that women are not N.F.L. fans.", "lead_paragraph": "SOME brands that are official sponsors of the National Football League could be construed to reinforce stereotypes about male fans, whether it\u2019s that they swill beer (Coors), laze on the couch eating pizza and snacks (Papa John\u2019s, Frito-Lay), or overindulge (Prilosec heartburn medication). {"abstract": "The Procter & Gamble Company said Friday that its quarterly profit rose 15 percent as sales gained in emerging markets, and forecast annual revenue that topped some analysts\u2019 estimates.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/06/business/emerging-markets-lift-results-at-procter-gamble.html", "snippet": "The Procter & Gamble Company said Friday that its quarterly profit rose 15 percent as sales gained in emerging markets, and forecast annual revenue that topped some analysts\u2019 estimates.", "lead_paragraph": "The Procter & Gamble Company said Friday that its quarterly profit rose 15 percent as sales gained in emerging markets, and forecast annual revenue that topped some analysts\u2019 estimates. Net income rose to $2.51 billion, or 84 cents a share, from $2.19 billion, or 71 cents a share, a year earlier, P.& G. said. The average estimate of 19 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg was for profit of 82 cents a share. Sales in the period, which ended June 30 and was the fourth quarter of Procter & Gamble\u2019s fiscal year, rose 10 percent to $20.9 billion, exceeding the $20.6 billion forecast by analysts. Wood pulp, resin and other materials cost Procter & Gamble $1 billion more than expected this year and prompted price increases, the chief financial officer, Jon R. Moeller, said on a conference call. Procter & Gamble\u2019s stock rose $1.01, to $60.59 a share. {"abstract": "Taking the fight to the court of public opinion can pay off for the smaller company.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/03/defending-david-against-goliath/", "snippet": "Taking the fight to the court of public opinion can pay off for the smaller company.", "lead_paragraph": "You may have seen a fascinating New York Times article about the lawsuit Procter & Gamble has filed against a start-up called Willa, which produces a line of cosmetics that is sold in Target and in small boutiques. It turns out that P.&G. has a line of cosmetics called Wella, a German hair care brand that the conglomerate acquired in 2003 for $7 billion. {"abstract": "The issue for Diamond Foods is no longer whether the government will find evidence of a violation, but how it will pursue enforcement actions under the range of remedies available.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/02/13/next-steps-in-diamond-foods-accounting-inquiry/", "snippet": "The issue for Diamond Foods is no longer whether the government will find evidence of a violation, but how it will pursue enforcement actions under the range of remedies available.", "lead_paragraph": "Investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department into accounting issues at Diamond Foods took on a new urgency after the company disclosed last week that it had put its chief executive, Michael J. Mendes, and chief financial officer, Steven J. Neil, on administrative leave over the accounting for expenses. {"abstract": "Prosecutors are seeking to have three wiretap recordings featuring the convicted hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam admitted as evidence at the trial of Rajat Gupta, a former Goldman Sachs board member.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/05/01/government-makes-case-for-wiretaps-against-gupta/", "snippet": "Prosecutors are seeking to have three wiretap recordings featuring the convicted hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam admitted as evidence at the trial of Rajat Gupta, a former Goldman Sachs board member.", "lead_paragraph": "Prosecutors are seeking to have three wiretap recordings featuring the convicted hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam admitted as evidence at the trial of Rajat Gupta, the former Goldman Sachs director accused of leaking inside information about the Wall Street firm. {"abstract": "Companies like Tide and General Motors are preparing for the N.F.L. season, which may be the most effective advertising delivery system ever invented.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/29/business/media/nfl-season-brings-ad-campaigns-from-tide-and-general-motors.html", "snippet": "Companies like Tide and General Motors are preparing for the N.F.L. season, which may be the most effective advertising delivery system ever invented.", "lead_paragraph": "LIKE children anticipating the arrival of Santa Claus, the marketers of Madison Avenue have circled next Wednesday on their calendars to herald the arrival of the 2012-13 National Football League season.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "3", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2012/08/29/business/ADCO-3/ADCO-3-articleLarge.jpg", "height": 330, "width": 600, "subType": "xlarge", "crop_name": "articleLarge", "legacy": {"xlarge": "images/2012/08/29/business/ADCO-3/ADCO-3-articleLarge.jpg", "xlargewidth": 600, "xlargeheight": 330}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "jumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2012/08/29/business/ADCO-3/ADCO-3-jumbo.jpg", "height": 683, "width": 1024, "subType": "jumbo", "crop_name": "jumbo", "legacy": {}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "superJumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2012/08/29/business/ADCO-3/ADCO-3-superJumbo.jpg", "height": 1366, "width": 2048, "subType": "superJumbo", "crop_name": "superJumbo", "legacy": {}}], "headline": {"main": "Companies Court 181 Million Viewers for N.F.L. {"abstract": "Online advertising shifts to follow consumers online, the BBC\u2019s legal woes mount, and how both sides in the conflict over Gaza are using social networks.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/16/the-breakfast-meeting-targeted-ads-reshape-online-media-and-gaza-conflict-on-the-internet/", "snippet": "Online advertising shifts to follow consumers online, the BBC\u2019s legal woes mount, and how both sides in the conflict over Gaza are using social networks.", "lead_paragraph": "Online advertising is shifting toward \u201cprogrammatic buying,\u201d a system that allows advertisers to follow individual consumers online, Tanzina Vega writes. It is a different method for reaching an online audience, one that gives less value to the context (that is, the writing, photos and video surrounding the ad) than to the individual who happens to visiting that particular site. Advertisers like Nike, Comcast, Progressive and Procter & Gamble are using programmatic buying and it is punishing traditional online publishers who are receiving a smaller share of ad dollars as marketers can buy across a broader range of sites.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast Meeting: Targeted Ads Reshape Online Media, and Gaza Conflict on the Internet", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Online Advertising", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Netanyahu, Benjamin", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Thompson, Mark John (1957- )", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "British Broadcasting Corp", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Gaza Strip", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-11-16T14:41:44+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Noam Cohen", "person": [{"firstname": "Noam", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Cohen", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/24cb5e2c-b9f2-5330-9fa1-c68a087f5706", "word_count": 518, "uri": "nyt://article/24cb5e2c-b9f2-5330-9fa1-c68a087f5706"}

{"abstract": "While unisex personal care products proliferated a generation ago, the shampoo aisle remained a haven for unisex products, but that, too, is shifting.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/18/business/media/in-shampoo-ads-for-men-its-not-just-the-hair-its-what-it-does-for-you.html", "snippet": "While unisex personal care products proliferated a generation ago, the shampoo aisle remained a haven for unisex products, but that, too, is shifting.", "lead_paragraph": "WHILE unisex personal care products proliferated a generation ago, today the antiperspirant and soap aisles, for example, are dominated by products marketed to just men or women. {"abstract": "Junior bankers are still working long hours despite new policies. | Four rival offers for Detroit\u2019s art could be an obstacle for the city as it tries to resolve its bankruptcy. | Ally prepares for its I.P.O. | Procter & Gamble sells most of its pet food brands to Mars.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/04/10/morning-agenda-junior-banker-blues/", "snippet": "Junior bankers are still working long hours despite new policies. | Four rival offers for Detroit\u2019s art could be an obstacle for the city as it tries to resolve its bankruptcy. | Ally prepares for its I.P.O. | Procter & Gamble sells most of its pe...", "lead_paragraph": "JUNIOR BANKERS STILL WORK LONG HOURS \u00a0|\u00a0 In the last six months, many of the biggest investment banks have signaled a sea change in their corporate culture, telling their most junior employees to ease up a bit on their hard-charging work schedules and take a few weekend days off. But like other practices on Wall Street, the more things change, the more they stay the same, William Alden and Sydney Ember write in DealBook.
